pin_cites.parenthetical: To assert the privilege against self-incrimination, the witness must refuse to answer questions or produce documents and must test the matter in a contempt proceeding or by habeas corpus.

"The Fifth Amendment privilege against compulsory self-incrimination ... protects 'a private inner sanctum of individual feeling and thought and proscribes state intrusion to extract self-condemnation'"

"The Fifth Amendment privilege against compulsory self-incrimination ... protects 'a private inner sanctum of individual feeling and thought and proscribes state intrusion to extract self-condemnation'"

"The Fifth Amendment privilege against compulsory self-incrimination ... protects 'a private inner sanctum of individual feeling and thought and proscribes state intrusion to extract self-condemnation'"
"It is for the court to say whether his silence is justified ... and to require him to answer if 'it clearly appears to the court that he is mistaken.' "
